title: Father of black woman shot and killed in her own home says 'unlike Botham Jean, I don't want no hug'
text:
A Fort Worth Police Department officer fatally shot an unarmed Atatiana Jefferson, 28 inside her own home in the Dallas metro area city early Saturday morning

The father of the black 28-year-old aspiring doctor who was unarmed when she was shot and killed by a police officer inside her own home early Saturday morning spoke to reporters for the first time Sunday night.

Marquis Jefferson told KTXA Dallas that his mother called him Saturday morning to tell him that his only daughter, Atatiana Jefferson, had been shot dead by an officer called to her home by a neighbor to make sure she and her family were OK.

Marquis called his daughter's homicide 'senseless.'

'My daughter was 28-year-old, had her whole life in front of her,' he said. 'You have to know this is somebody's daughter. Somebody loved her. There was a better way. It didn't have to be like that.'

James Smith was the neighbor who called police around 2.30am to check on Atatiana, who served as a caregiver to an elderly relative who also lived next door.

Scroll down for video

Fort Worth Police have declined to name the officer who fired a fatal shot into Jefferson's window after seeing her walk by during a welfare check around 2.30am on Saturday

Atatiana Jefferson's dad, Marquis Jefferson, told a reporter his daughter's shooting death by a Fort Worth Police Department officer was 'senseless'

Marquis Jefferson and his wife, Noella Jefferson (right), told KTXA Dallas that Marquis's mother called him Saturday morning to tell him that his only daughter, Atatiana, had been shot dead by an officer called to her home by a neighbor to make sure she and her family were OK

The 28-year-old and her eight-year-old nephew were playing video games when they heard a noise outside that they thought was a prowler, according to the family's attorney S. Lee Merritt, who has spoken with the child witness.

Atatiana went to the window after hearing the noises, Merritt said. It was there she was confronted by a white Fort Worth police officer who did not identify himself to her before telling her, 'Put your hands up. Show me your hands.'

A split second later, the officer opened fire, killing Jefferson. The case is being compared to the fatal of shooting of Botham Jean, who was also fatally shot by a police officer in his home just over a year ago.

Marquis Jefferson recalled Jean's brother, Brandt Jean, begging to hug the elder Jean's killer, fired Dallas Police Officer Amber Guyger, during her sentencing hearing on October 2.

Noella Jefferson said her step-daughter had hopes, dreams and aspirations that she will never be able to fulfill now

Atatiana Jefferson, 28, was fatally shot by a Fort Worth Police Department officer while standing inside her own home unarmed early Saturday morning

The father of the late 28-year-old did not express the said there won't be any such sentimentality for him about the officer who killed his daughter.

'Unlike this Botham Jean, I don't want no hug,' he said. 'That's my one and only daughter. I will never forget that.'

Atatiana's step mother, Noella Jefferson, said her step-daughter had hopes, dreams and aspirations that she will never be able to fulfill now.

Atatiana graduated with a pre-med degree from Xavier University of Louisiana in 2014.

'We have lost her for no reason,' Noella said. 'We have seen many cases like this where you think that they would have learned from it.'

A photo of Tatiana Jefferson serving ion her local high school band in 2005-2006

Neighbor James Smith told reporters he called police on the local non-emergency line to do a welfare check on Jefferson's home after he saw her front door open some time after 2am on Saturday

Atatiana's aunt, Venitta Body, told reporters her family does not understand why she was killed.

'It's like from the moment we got the call, it's been more and more inconceivable and more confusing. And there has nothing been done in order to take away that confusion,' Body said.

The victim's sister, Amber Carr, said her shooting death is 'another one of those situations where the people that are supposed to protect us are actually not here to protect us.'

'You know, you want to see justice, but justice don't bring my sister back,' Carr added.

family's attorney S. Lee Merritt, said the unnamed officer's bodycam footage showed the cop 'didn't have time to perceive a threat. That's murder'

Local minister and activist Rev. Kyev Tatum of Ministers Against Crime and the 3E coalition called on Texas Gov. Greg Abbott and Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick to travel to Fort Worth to address the shooting

Police Lt. Brandon O'Neil said Sunday afternoon that the officer who pulled the trigger has been on the force since April 2018.

He has been placed on paid administrative leave pending the outcome of an investigation and will be interviewed about the fatal shooting on Monday.

The officer's name was not released.

Local activists marched through the streets of Fort Worth Sunday evening venting their outrage and frustration in the aftermath of the latest police shooting death of an unarmed black person in their own home.

Attorney Lee Merritt spoke to reporters after watching the officer's body cam video.

'You didn't hear the officer shout, "Gun, gun, gun". He didn't have time to perceive a threat. That's murder,' Merritt said.

The Fort Worth Police Department said in a statement that officers saw someone near a window inside the home and that one of them drew his duty weapon and fired after 'perceiving a threat,' the Associated Press reported.

They released images showing a handgun they said officers found inside Jefferson's home, but did not say where the gun was discovered or whether the officer who shot Jefferson saw it before pulling the trigger.

Carol Harrison-Lafayette protests the police shooting of Atatiana Jefferson during a community vigil for Jefferson on Sunday

Protesters gather outside the house where Atatiana Jefferson was shot Saturday

A large crowd gathered outside Jefferson's home Sunday night for a vigil after earlier demonstrations briefly stopped traffic on part of Interstate 35.

At a brief news conference at police headquarters, O'Neil confirmed that the officer did not announce he was police before he fired the fatal shot and that his failure to do so is part of the department's investigation.

O'Neil also confirmed that Jefferson's eight-year-old nephew was in the room with Jefferson when she was shot.

He said representatives of the police department have spoken with the woman's family and 'shared our serious and heartfelt concern for this unspeakable loss.'

O'Neil declined to answer reporters' questions and said Fort Worth Police Chief Ed Kraus plans to conduct a more in-depth news conference on Monday.

Trinity Ford, 4, joins the crowd gathered during a Sunday community vigil for Atatiana Jefferson

Additional Facebook photos of Atatiana Jefferson

Atatiana was an aspiring med student who graduated with a pre-med degree from Xavier University of Louisiana in 2014

James Smith, who called a police non-emergency number about the open door, told reporters he was just trying to be a good neighbor.

'I'm shaken. I'm mad. I'm upset. And I feel it's partly my fault,' Smith said. 'If I had never dialed the police department, she'd still be alive.'

Smith said Jefferson and her nephew typically lived with an older woman, who's been in the hospital.

'It makes you not want to call the police department,' he said.

Atatiana's family said she was playing video games with her eight-year-old nephew early Saturday morning just before she was shot

The victim's family said she and her nephew thought they heard a prowler outside shortly before she walked in front of a window in their Fort Worth home

Body cam footage of the incident shows the responding officer who shot Jefferson never told her he was a police man before opening fire a split second after telling her to 'show me your hands'

The police department said they recovered a handgun from the home, but did not say where the gun was found in the home or whether the officer who shot Jefferson saw the weapon before opening fire

In an audio recording of Smith's call that was released by police, the neighbor said it was 'not normal' for the house to leave its front door open for hours at that time of day.

Merritt said Jefferson's family expects 'a thorough and expedient investigation.'

The Fort Worth Police Department said it released bodycam footage soon after the shooting to provide transparency, but that any 'camera footage inside the residence' could not be distributed due to state law.

However, the bodycam video released to media included blurred still frames showing a gun inside a bedroom at the home.

This statement on Atatiana Jefferson's police shooting death was released by the Fort Worth Police Department on Saturday

The police statement released Saturday said only that officers who entered the residence after the shooting found a firearm. Police did not immediately respond to a message seeking comment Sunday.

Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders on Sunday called on the Justice Department to investigate.

'The killings of unarmed Black Americans have got to end,' Sanders tweeted. 'Atatiana Jefferson should be alive.'

Local minister and activist Rev. Kyev Tatum of Ministers Against Crime and the 3E coalition called on Texas Gov. Greg Abbott and Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick to travel to Fort Worth to address the shooting with the local community to help quell anger and address the issue of police shooting unarmed civilians in their own homes.

Destinie and Floriberto Bartolo mourn for their friend Atatiana Jefferson, who they say they have known since high school, outside the house where Jefferson was shot and killed by a police officer, during a community vigil for Jefferson on Sunday

Police Lt. Brandon O'Neil called Jefferson's death an 'unspeakable loss'

'Our young people are not going to tolerate this, no matter how much we tell them to be cool, remain calm, that justice will be served,' Kyev told WFAA. 'When another mother loses her wife, a caregiver for both her eight-year-old nephew and a grandparent, loses her life in her own home, there's something grossly wrong with the Fort Worth Police Department and they refuse to take responsibility for their actions.'

The video released by police shows two officers searching the home from the outside with flashlights before one shouts, 'Put your hands up, show me your hands.' One shot is then fired through a window.

The man who pulled the trigger never identifies himself as police to Jefferson. The police department so far has declined to release the name of the offending officer.

But they told WFAA he is a white man who has been with the department since April of last year. He has been placed on paid administrative leave.
description: The father of the black 28-year-old aspiring doctor shot and killed by a police officer inside her own home early Saturday morning spoke to reporters for the first time Sunday night.
